objdescid.origination: Anonymous delineator. The reference to Judges, lower right of the design, might be by Blake. The quotation from the Bible, lower on the leaf and available under Related Works in the Archive, is not by Blake. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the quotation from the Bible is not known.
objdescid.compdate:
c. 1800-03
This work was probably delivered to Butts between the summer of 1803 and May 1805 (Bentley, *Records* , page 764), but has generally been dated to an earlier period, c. 1800-03, for stylistic reasons; see Butlin 455.

objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, and water color

provenance.name: Philadelphia Museum of Art
provenance.note: Commissioned, perhaps as early as 1800, and acquired, by 1805, from Blake by Thomas Butts; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; by inheritance in 1862 to Captain F. J. Butts; offered Sotheby's, 24 June 1903, lot 6 (£50 to "Knowles," but apparently not sold and returned to Butts); the widow of F. J. Butts, sold April 1906 through Carfax & Co. to W. Graham Robertson; sold Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 13 (£861 to the dealer Thomas Agnew & Sons); David Eccles; sold Nov. 1956 by Agnew's through the dealer Charles Sessler to Mrs. William T. Tonner ($4,435); bequeathed by Tonner in 1964 to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, which received the work in 1972.

lg.l: And she made him sleep on her knees and she called for a man, and she caused
him to shave off the seven locks of his head.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design, based on Judges 16:19, represents the Biblical scene of Delilah cutting Samson's hair to weaken him. In the center of the design is a bare-breasted woman who may wear a skirt or some cloth draped over her legs; this is Delilah. She has long, curly hair and appears to wear an earring in her visible left ear. She sits, twisted, so that her legs face right, her torso faces forward, and her head faces left. Both legs are bent, with her right foot visible and possibly on tiptoe. Her left arm is at her side but bent and she holds a pair of scissors in her left hand. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and she points upward with her right hand, fingers spread; presumably, she uses this gesture to summon the soldiers toward whom she looks. Sitting limply and partly reclining, with a nearly bald head resting on Delilah's lap, is the nude and muscular male figure of Samson. He faces away and slightly left. His arms are at his side and his legs are bent underneath him. He is probably sleeping. His right hand rests limply on bedding; both feet are prominent. On the left side of the design stand three armored soldiers, wearing helmets. The two frontmost soldiers have mustaches, bend forward, and face forward and right. Their right feet are prominent; the may be striding forward. The soldier on the left appears to look at Sampson; his companion on the right looks at Delilah. The face of the middle figure is obscured but is probably also facing right. The two soldiers in front carry two shields; the soldier on the right also holds a spear. The knees of the two soldiers in front are covered in scale-like armor or perhaps chainmail. The presence of four speaks behind the soldiers indicate at least three more soldiers that are not pictured. The scene takes place in a room or tent defined primarily by the drapery behind Delilah. Delilah and Samson appear to sit on a couch or bed, which is covered in draping cloth, possibly a sheet.
